channel.title: Sharing space in drives
channel.description:
Hey guys, had no where else to turn and I know I'll get an answer here.
I have two drives, (C:) has 12GB and (D:) has 100GB. I didn't even look at this until recently when I noticed I had low memory. I found out that my (C:) was completely full and my (D:) was completely empty. Now I googled around a bit and found out there's a way to share the memory so it can all be just one drive with 112GB of space. I downloaded Paragon Hard Disk Manager but I have to buy it for it to let me share the space. Friend of mine told me I could do that somehow on my own computer without downloading anything but he didn't know how. Googled a lot again and still no answers.
Please help Thanks

item.title: Sharing space in drives
item.dc:creator: @kaza Kaza
item.description:
@kaza wrote:

Download some partition manager, move everything from (D:) onto a DVD or external HDD or something. Then delete (D:) and you should have (C:) and “Unallocated Space”, then you should be able to change the size of (C:).

Acronis is a good partition manager, torrent it.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @FastBallz FastBawlz
item.description:
@FastBallz wrote:

pk4pk:

Yeah but 1 TB is expensive. I’m not going to waist all that money on a computer.

Where are you buying this from? You payed $150 for a 200GB, while you can get a 1TB HD for $140.

xEnt:

4gig? a “downloads only” computer would run fine on 1gig ram. a true downloads computer would have a few tb’s or more space, your’s is like a Home Theater PC.

Yeah but 1 TB is expensive. I’m not going to waist all that money on a computer.

item.dc:creator: @FastBallz FastBawlz
item.description:
@FastBallz wrote:

[quote=“pk4pk, post:12, topic:231022”]I’ve got a computer with an 520 Gig hard drive

But it’s spec’s are only good for downloads…

Ram - 4 gigs

Interwebs - COMCAST

Windows XP Media center edition

Graphics card Nvidia GeForce 6150 =[

Amd Athlon 6400 X2 dual core proccesor

This is the ultimate computer for downloading.

Going at a speed of 6200 KB/S

[Cost $850.00 As it was on sale and my Dad is a manager at BestBuy][/quote]

Who gives a shit?

Besides the fact that what really affects dl speed is your ISP.

item.title: Sharing space in drives
item.dc:creator: @pk4pk pk4pk
item.description:
@pk4pk wrote:

I’ve got a computer with an 520 Gig hard drive

But it’s spec’s are only good for downloads…

Ram - 4 gigs

Interwebs - COMCAST

Windows XP Media center edition

Graphics card Nvidia GeForce 6150 =[

Amd Athlon 6400 X2 dual core proccesor

This is the ultimate computer for downloading.

Going at a speed of 6200 KB/S

[Cost $850.00 As it was on sale and my Dad is a manager at BestBuy]

[HDD upgrade was $150.00 for another 200 gigs] We use this as our Work/Shit installer

Around 200 gigs have been used.

My D: Partion has only 6 Gigs for recovery only.

Why wont you just buy a new HDD and transfer the files?

Read full topic

item.title: Sharing space in drives
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

few years ago i used to use this dos program called norton ghost, pretty much compresses everything on your current partition into 1 file, which you can restore everything back that was in it if your computer fucks up.

delete everything, install your OS, drivers and programs (not games or music) on your main, use something like ghost to make a compressed file of everything on your main hdd after a nice installation, put that file on your 12gb and use the leftover should be at least 6gigs, as a page file. Same shit k00dr said really.

Read full topic

item.title: Sharing space in drives
item.dc:creator: @k00dr k00dr
item.description:
@k00dr wrote:

If they are physical drives, then I agree. Although I’d also recommend putting the hibernation file and system restore -shit on the smaller one aswell.

Read full topic

item.title: Sharing space in drives
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

solution, use the 12gb drive as a page file and use the 100gb as a main.

Read full topic

item.title: Sharing space in drives
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

assuming you have two partitions, not drives:

solution: leave all windows related files and installed programs on the first drive, transfer all personal data like music etc onto the second drive

… or just delete the D partition, and resize the C one

Read full topic

item.title: Sharing space in drives
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

Moparisthebest:

If you have 2 different physical harddrives you cannot do that. Why not just transfer stuff to the 100GB drive and install stuff to it in the future?

yes you can

Read full topic

item.title: Sharing space in drives
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Just put your OS on the 12GB disk and the rest on the other one. IIRC you get a speed win from it.

Read full topic

item.title: Sharing space in drives
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:3, topic:231022”]Yes, you can do it on XP without extra software, XP supports “dynamic disks” which are pretty much software emulated RAID, but shittier (fine for what you want to do).

Might be XP Pro only, not Home, i can’t remember.

http://support.microsoft.com/default.aspx?scid=kb;en-us;Q308424

^ All you need to know.

(If you’re on Vista, I have no idea)[/quote]

Neat, never heard of that before.

IScrubs:

To Mopar: I’d rather have them together, feels more organized but it won’t let me so I’m going to do what ya said. Would there be a problem if I just move all my program files to (D:)?

Some programs create registry entries and will only let it run from the installed directory, but many programs do not. It will be hit and miss.

Read full topic

item.description:

item.title: Sharing space in drives
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Yes, you can do it on XP without extra software, XP supports “dynamic disks” which are pretty much software emulated RAID, but shittier (fine for what you want to do).

Might be XP Pro only, not Home, i can’t remember.

http://support.microsoft.com/default.aspx?scid=kb;en-us;Q308424

^ All you need to know.

(If you’re on Vista, I have no idea)

Read full topic
